qas.question: Who was planning an invasion of the Soviet Union?

Why did Stalin sign the pact?

answers.text: reinforce a public affection for Germany

qas.question: Who wasn't planning an invasion of the Soviet Union?
Who was openly planning an invasion of the Soviet Union?

plausible_answers.text: to reinforce a public affection for Germany

qas.question: Why didn't Stalin sign the pact?

context: In an effort to demonstrate peaceful intentions toward Germany, on 13 April 1941, the Soviets signed a neutrality pact with Axis power <b5_0><b6_0>Japan<b6_0/><b5_0/>. While Stalin had little faith in <a1_0>Japan<a1_0/>'s commitment to neutrality, he felt that the pact was important for its political symbolism, <b7_0>to <a2_0>reinforce a public affection for Germany<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Stalin felt that there was a growing split in German circles about whether Germany should initiate a war with the Soviet Union. Stalin did not know that <b3_0><b4_0>Hitler<b4_0/><b3_0/> had been secretly discussing an invasion of the Soviet Union since summer 1940, and that <a0_0>Hitler<a0_0/> had ordered his military in late 1940 to prepare for war in the east regardless of the parties' talks of a potential Soviet entry as a fourth Axis Power.
